security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only skill containing pure markdown guidance. All static findings are false positives triggered by pattern matching on documentation text. The bash command examples document standard git worktree operations with hardcoded arguments (git ls, grep, git worktree add). The skill explicitly includes safety practices: .gitignore verification before creating worktrees and test baseline verification. No executable code, network access, credential handling, or persistence mechanisms exist.

content.value_statement: Managing multiple branches in a single git repository clutters your workflow and interrupts active work. This skill creates isolated worktrees where you can work on features without modifying your main working directory.
actual_capabilities: Create isolated git worktrees in project-local or global directories
Auto-detect project type and run appropriate setup commands
Verify .gitignore configuration before creating project-local worktrees
Run project tests to establish a clean baseline
Follow directory priority: existing folders > CLAUDE.md preferences > user input
limitations: Requires git version 2.5 or newer for worktree support
Cannot work with repositories that have uncommitted changes in the working tree
Does not manage worktree cleanup or removal

best_practices: Always verify .gitignore contains the worktree directory before creating project-local worktrees
Establish a clean test baseline before making changes to detect regressions early
Follow the directory priority order: existing folders > CLAUDE.md preferences > ask user
anti_patterns: Creating worktrees without checking .gitignore first (risks committing worktree contents)
Skipping baseline test verification (cannot distinguish new bugs from pre-existing issues)
Hardcoding a single directory location instead of following project conventions

faq.question: Which git versions support worktrees?
faq.answer: Git worktrees require version 2.5 or newer. Check with git --version before using this skill.

faq.question: Where should I store worktree directories?
faq.answer: Prefer project-local (.worktrees/) for convenience, or global (~/.config/superpowers/worktrees/) to avoid cluttering projects.

faq.question: Does this skill work with all project types?
faq.answer: Yes, it auto-detects Node.js, Rust, Python, and Go projects and runs appropriate setup commands.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using worktrees?
faq.answer: Worktrees share the repository history. The skill verifies .gitignore to prevent accidental commits of worktree contents.

faq.question: What happens if tests fail during baseline verification?
faq.answer: The skill reports failures and asks whether to proceed or investigate before making any changes.

faq.question: How is this different from git stash?
faq.answer: Worktrees create separate working directories. You can work on multiple branches simultaneously without hiding changes.
